getYourHandDirty.title: Step 2. Get Your Hands Dirty
getYourHandDirty.p1: Better understand the previous theory by getting some hands-on experience of CKB blockchain.

studyAChain.title: Study a Chain
studyAChain.p1: We have been running a test chain over the cloud and have pre-generated some account addresses for this tutorial.
studyAChain.p2: Click on the buttons below and check out the latest blocks.
studyAChain.p4: Try hovering over the wallets to open them.
studyAChain.p5: Each wallet carries four messages, meant as follows:

ul1.l1: mainnet: indicates the mainnet address of the wallet
ul1.l2: testnet: indicates the testnet address of the wallet. In this tutorial, we only use the testnet addresses
ul1.l3: lock_arg: indicates the first 20 bits of the wallet's corresponding public key hash. Think of it simply as a fingerprint of the public key.
ul1.l4: private_key: the private key of the wallet. You should not expose it as what I did.

studyAChain.p6: In this tutorial, these three wallets will be used to send transactions, deploy contracts and some other purposes.
studyAChain.p7: Now, you can select any of these wallets to review the associated cell and transactions by clicking on the button below.
studyAChain.p8: Click on any cells or transactions to see the details in JSON format.
studyAChain.p9: By saying how many CKBs (native tokens) a wallet has, we refer to the sum of the capacity of all the live cells that the wallet can unlock, i. e. the total on-chain storage the wallet occupies.
studyAChain.p10: Now, Wallet 1 serves as the default miner address on this test chain.
studyAChain.p11: In other words, Wallet 1 will continuously receive rewards generated by mining. As a result, Wallet 1 has the most live cells, while Wallets 2 and 3 have very few, if any, live cells.
studyAChain.p12: Currently, there is only one miner on the test chain.
studyAChain.p13: At last, we also need to know the configuration information of this test chain.
studyAChain.p15: indicates that this chain is the test chain rather than the mainnet.
studyAChain.p16: represent the built-in smart contracts, i.e. some of the system's built-in locks that type and lock can use.
studyAChain.p17: Each CKB chain will pre-deploy several built-in smart contracts in the genesis block. Here it displays the details of three system contracts. They are:

ul2.l1: SECP256K1_BLAKE160: the system's default contract for the lock lock of the cell, used to protect the ownership of the cell
ul2.l2: SECP256K1_BLAKE160_MULTISIG: the multi-signature version of SECP256K1_BLAKE160
ul2.l3: DAO: NervosDAO contract. Feel free to ignore it if you don't understand.

studyAChain.p18: Well, that's all the information we need to know.
studyAChain.p19: Now, we are about to build and send our first transaction!

class1.title: Send a Transaction
class1.p1: In this section, we will have a hands-on lesson on how to complete a basic transfer transaction.
class1.p2: A quick refresher before we start:
class1.p3: A CKB transaction is nothing more than spending some existing live cells and creating some new ones.
class1.p4: Because CKB is designed as â€œoff-chain computing, on-chain verifyingâ€, we can complete a transfer operation by collaging transactions manually.
class1.p5: As long as we draw up the content of the transaction in advance (i.e., which cells will be spent and which new cells will be created), then we sign the transaction with the corresponding private key. Once the transaction is submitted to the chain, as long as it passes the verification and is signed in a validated manner, this transaction is completed and will be packaged.
class1.p6: What does such a manual collage of transactions mean?
class1.p7: Actually, we compose the layer 2 in a network system like CKB.
class1.p8: Imagine you have a friend now living isolated in the Amazon jungle, with nothing but an offline computer next to him.
class1.p9: One afternoon, he returned home from a hunting trip and suddenly remembered that he owed you some money. So he turned on the computer and attempted to transfer 10,000 CKBs to you to settle his debt.
class1.p10: Despite the lack of internet access, he wrote down the transaction details on a piece of paper, then entered his private key into the computer, calculated the corresponding signature for the transfer, and attached his signature.
class1.p11: Half a month later, when a courier visited, he asked to send this paper to China by mail. Another half a month later, the letter finally reached you.
class1.p12: You read the letter. The message did specify the transaction of 10,000 CKB cells to you. So you decided to submit the transaction to the CKB mainnet.
class1.p13: The mainnet validated the attached signature, the transaction was completed, leaving you with 10,000 more CKBs in your account. The debt was cleared.
class1.p14: Despite the low throughputâ€”only 1 transaction/month, you and your Amazon jungle buddy have thus created a layer2 network that contains 2 nodes.
class1.p15: CKB now has a variety of tools to help you auto-build transactions, transfer and deploy contracts, etc. However, we'll stick to this old-school approach to implement a regular transfer transaction.
class1.p16: This is intended to give you a deeper insight into how the CKB cells work by using manually assembled transactions.
class1.p17: We will use JSON format to do this.

transactionInput.title: Transaction Input
transactionInput.p1: Below are the 4 live cells from Wallet 1. Drag the cells directly into the box underneath. See what the automatically generated input looks like.
transactionInput.p2: You probably noticed that the cell in input appears in the form of previous_output, which is imported as an â€œout_pointâ€ composed of tx_hash and indexâ€”comparable to an index, or a pointer to the cellâ€”by which we can locate the cell to be spent.
transactionInput.p3: The  since field in the input is about to control the time. Don't bother with it for now.
transactionInput.p4: Other than inputs, there is another field called cell_deps that a transaction needs to depend on. It also appears as an index result of the outpoint.
transactionInput.p6: For instance, in a regular transfer transaction, the lock lock requires a fixed encryption algorithm, SECP256K1_BLAKE160, a built-in smart contract. The code of this encryption algorithm is kept in a cell and needs to be referenced in cell_deps, so that CKB-VM knows where to import the code for calculation.
transactionInput.p7: We can easily find the arguments we need to send in cell_deps by checking the configuration information demonstrated in the test chain above.

transactionOutput.title: Transaction Output
transactionOutput.p1: Next, let's use another tool to see how the output is generated and how the complete transaction looks like.
transactionOutput.p2: Again, drag the cell from Wallet 1 to *INPUT*.
transactionOutput.p3: A new cell of an identical size will be automatically generated in OUTPUT.
transactionOutput.p4: Click the *Setting* button in *OUTPUT* to reassign the newly generated cells, including specifying how many cells to generate, setting the size and the unlock address of each cell, and so on.
transactionOutput.p5: The output must take up less capacity than the input, and the gap is the fee to reward miners.
transactionOutput.p6: After setting it up, click the *Generate Transaction* button to see the JSON of the transaction.
transactionOutput.p7: You may have noticed that the outputs of the transaction have written out all the information about the newly generated cell, including capacity size, lock lock, etc.
transactionOutput.p8: However, the data is not specified in the cell in the output; the data is located in the outputs_data field, which corresponds to the cells in the outputs accordingly. Again, this is designed for performance optimization.
transactionOutput.p9: A complete transaction also includes version and header_deps. The former suggests the versionâ€”currently set as 0x0, while the latter is left blank for now.

signTheTransaction.title: Sign a Transaction
signTheTransaction.p1: Once a transaction has been assembled, a private key needs to be assigned to sign the transaction. The private key indicates that we are truly the owner of the cells and entitled to operate on them.
signTheTransaction.p2: The signature will then be put into a new field called witnesses, which serves as proof of the transaction.
signTheTransaction.p3: Now you have a complete understanding of how a transaction works. Let's move forward to the step of sending transactions.

buildATransaction.title: Build a Transaction
buildATransaction.p1: Now, fill in the transaction information in the blanks below.
buildATransaction.p2: Use this as an exercise to complete a transfer transaction by yourself.
buildATransaction.p3: You may need to use some functions such as to locate the live cells corresponding to your wallet, to view the chain config info (so you can fill in cell_deps), and to convert from hex to decimal, etc., all of which can be found in the toolbox on the right side.
buildATransaction.p4: Click the Nervos icon to open the box. ğŸ‘‰
buildATransaction.p5: Click on the *Save* button after filling it out.
buildATransaction.p6: Well, you have filled in all the transactions manually.
buildATransaction.p7: We can now generate a unique hash for the transaction, which is to say, the tx_hash can be generated beforehand.

generateTxHash.title: Generate Transaction Hash
generateTxHash.p1: Click the button below to generate the hash of the transaction.
generateTxHash.p2: While the transaction can generate tx_hash beforehand, so far it is still a raw_tx. raw_tx differs from tx in that tx puts the signature of the transaction in the witnesses field.
generateTxHash.p3: In fact, you can put any arguments or proofs you need in witnesses. Also, being an array, witness can include multiple proofs. Since we are now talking about the built-in transfer transaction, the mutual agreement is to put the following structure in the first position of each set of witnesses:
generateTxHash.p4: This structure is called WitnessArgs. Different locks retrieve each signature required from the different fields of WitnessArgs.
generateTxHash.p5: The lock field is the signature that needs to be verified for the lock that the input will use. In our case, this is the signature required by the SECP256K1_BLAKE160 algorithm to be verified.
generateTxHash.p6: The input_type and output_type fields are the signatures required for the type locks in input and output. But feel free to ignore them for now.
generateTxHash.p7: Signature is a tedious process. More technical details can be found here:

generateMessage.title: Generate  Message
generateMessage.p1: To complete the signature, let's generate a message which will be signed for this transaction.

completeSining.title: Complete the Signature
completeSining.p1: With the message and the private key of our wallet, we can calculate the signature.

putBackSignature.title: Put the Signature Back to Transaction
putBackSignature.p1: Fill in the following input box with the generated signature. Click on the button to serialize in the form of witnessArgs :
putBackSignature.p2: Now it's time to finalize the original transaction by putting the serialized signature into the witnesses field.

sendTransaction.title: Send the Transaction
sendTransaction.p1: Finally, the last step. Now we send the transaction back on-chain.
sendTransaction.p2: Congratulations on completing the first section of this tutorial!
sendTransaction.p3: We will then learn how to send a multi-signature transfer transaction.
